EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0	Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Kraft Heinz Foods Company facility in Tulare, California has an excellent record in preventing releases of anhydrous* ammonia.  This facility submitted the initial RMP in June 1999.  This is a re-submittal as required by anniversary date.  There have been no reportable ammonia releases since the initial RMP was filed.  This facility has implemented an electronic preventive maintenance system.  This is a system that uses a real time database to track preventive maintenance, training, inspection dates and issue reminders to responsible groups.  Training is tracked on an internal spreadsheet.

The emergency response policies at the Tulare facility ensure that there is emergency response coverage 24 hours per day and 7 days per week through employees with emergency response training.  There are also adequate provisions for coordination with outside agencies, such as the Tulare City Fire Department, in the event of an emergency.
*From this point in the Executive Summary, anhydrous ammonia will be synonymous with ammonia.

2.0	Process Description and Regulated Substances

The Tulare, CA plant is a manufacturer/processor of dairy products and dairy byproducts. The North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes for the primary processes at this facility are 311512 and 311513.   The facility is capable of producing and packaging various dairy products for consumer intake.  Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to preserve the dairy products.  Some of these areas include: storage tanks and silos containing raw materials and product.

The Tulare plant has one regulated substance under 40 CFR 68: ammonia.  Ammonia is used as a cooling agent in the plant's refrigeration process. 

The ammonia threshold for triggering applicability to 40 CFR 68 is 10,000 pounds. The quantity of ammonia stored on-site is 86,000 pounds.  Thus, 40 CFR 68 is applicable to Kraft Heinz Foods Co

mpany in Tulare.

3.0	Worst-case and Alternative Release Scenarios
 
The ammonia refrigeration system has associated hazards that can potentially affect on-site employees and the general public if there is a release from the system. Although the alternative release scenario is more probable, the US EPA requires that one worst-case and one alternative release scenario is reported for each regulated chemical. Described below are the associated hazards and the worst-case and alternative release scenarios for each regulated chemical.

Ammonia 

Ammonia is classified as a Group 2 Refrigerant per ASHRAE Standard 34-1989.  The dominant characteristic of this chemical is its toxicity.  It is a self-alarming chemical by its distinctive pungent odor.  Due to this odor, persons exposed to ammonia vapor will not voluntarily stay in areas of even small concentrations.  Ammonia is flammable in a very narrow and high range of concentration with a high ignition temperature.  It is not poisonous, but it is corrosive to human tissue.  Ammonia is readily absorbed into the moisture of the skin and, at high concentrations, can cause severe burns.

The risks to persons in an accidental release of ammonia include:

1.	Irritation of respiratory tract,
2.	Corrosive attack of skin and other tissue,
3.	Freezing of skin and other body tissue when contacted by liquid ammonia.

Below is a description of the release scenarios for ammonia and their off-site consequences:

Worst-case scenario - The largest potential release of ammonia will occur with a puncture in the high-pressure receiver (HPR) located outside on the west side of the plant approximately 150 yards from the property line. The vessel size is 84" x 288" OAL. It is industry practice that a vessel is not filled over 80%, this engineering control is used in determining the total amount of pounds released for the worst case scenario. The Kraft Heinz Foods Company-Tulare plant has a total of 86,000 pounds of ammonia in t

he one covered process. The total amount of pounds in the High Pressure Receiver at 80°F is estimated at 29,787.6, which was rounded to 29,788 for RMP Comp. The worst-case scenario (OCA1) calculations consider the High Pressure Receiver releasing 29,788 lbs. of ammonia over ten-minute period, which produces a circle of concern with a radius of 3.1 miles.
 
Under Section 68.25(c)(1), a regulated toxic substance such as ammonia, which is normally a gas at ambient temperature and handled as a liquid under pressure, shall be considered to be released as a gas over a 10-minute period.  Thus, ammonia's physical state in the worst-case release is a gas.

 	The ammonia worst-case scenario was modeled using EPA's RMP*COMP to obtain the distance to endpoint.  The endpoint is defined by the US EPA as the Emergency Response Planning Guideline, Level A 2 (ERPG-2) which was calculated to be 3 .1 miles.  The ERPG-2 was developed by the American Industrial Hygiene Association and is applicable to human exposures for up to one hour.  The ERPG-2 is intended to protect individuals from health threatening or escape impairing injury and is not generally considered fatal.

Rural dispersion coefficients were used during the modeling runs for the Tulare facility in accordance with Appendix W to Part 51 A Guidelines on Air Quality Models Section 8.2.8.

The estimated affected residential population is 2,044 people.  The types of affected receptors are listed in EPA's RMP*SUBMIT.

	Alternative Release Scenario - This scenario is more likely to occur than the worst-case release. The alternative release scenario should reach an endpoint off-site.  

Based on a review of facility operating history, Process Hazard Analysis and knowledge of industry incidents, the following are key alternative release scenarios considered for the Hazard Assessment of this site. 

1. Liquid Pump Seal Failure

2. Relief Valve Discharge

Scenario 2, although may occur, would not result in any offsi

te consequences as all relief valves are routed to a diffusion tank at the facility. Thus, scenario 1 was chosen. Such a scenario might occur through damage an open drive liquid ammonia pump. For ammonia liquefied under pressure, the following equation [10] can be used to estimate the release rate.

QR = 203 × A (lower power h) ×	square root P (lower power g)


Where:

QR = Ammonia Release Rate (lbs per minute)

Ah = Hole or Puncture area (square inches)

Pg   = Container Pressure (psig)


The hole/puncture area was calculated assuming a 1/8" diameter circular hole.  The container pressure was conservatively assumed to be at the pressure relief valves set point of 250 psig. The mass flow rate of ammonia was then calculated to be 39.5 lbs./min and would release
2,370 lbs. of ammonia in 60 minutes. The calculated release rate and leak duration were entered into RMP*Comp [3], producing a circle of concern with a radius of 0.1 miles.  

No matter the scenario chosen for the alternate case scenario, Marplot indicates that the closest (population) receptors are not reached for 1.0 miles.   In order to get a 1.0-mile alternate case distance to toxic endpoint in RMPComp, the facility would have to release approximately 28,000 pounds, which is slightly less than the worst case scenario and highly unlikely for an alternate case.

The endpoint is defined by the US EPA as the Emergency Response Planning Guideline, Level A 2 (ERPG-2) which was calculated to be 0.1 miles.  The estimated affected residential population is 8 people.  

4.0	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Tulare plant has developed an OSHA PSM program for their ammonia refrigeration system. Ammonia falls under the RMP Program 3 prevention program, which is identical to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program.    EPA has said that if the process is in compliance with OSHA PSM, then it is compliance with RMP Program 3.  Thus, the Tulare facility ammonia PSM should meet the requirements for the RMP document.  

There are several aspects of the prevention program that are key: 

1.	Since most of the pipework is out of the way of people and the machinery, there is less of a chance of an ammonia release.
2.	The plant maintains good training, certification and employee awareness of operating procedures.
3.	The plant has developed a strong preventive maintenance and inspection program.
4.	An ammonia detection system is present at the facility that alerts facility personnel
5.	Utility personnel are present on-site and assigned to the ammonia system 24 hours a day, 7 days a week and all year round


5.0	Five-year Accident History

The review of this facility's accident history includes the following range of dates: June 1, 2004 A¿ May 31, 2009. According to 40 CFR Part 68.42(a), there have been no accidental releases, for ammonia, at this facility.

6.0	Emergency Response Program

The facility has a w

ritten emergency response plan.  Kraft Heinz Foods Company ORM Department and the Tulare City Fire Department have reviewed this plan.

The plant personnel are divided into various management and response teams.  The in-plant contacts in the event of an emergency are listed in the Plant Emergency response Plan.  Back-up personnel are also available in the event that the primary incident response personnel cannot be contacted.  The on-site emergency response plan includes information about the frequency of employee emergency response training as well as a detailed description of the training content.  There are also specific procedures to follow in the event of a fire and ammonia emergency.

At the discretion of the Incident Coordinator, the Tulare City Fire Department will be called upon to provide back-up emergency responders and equipment.  The Tulare City Fire Department responds to all emergencies where fire alarms are used for evacuation in addition to all fire related emergencies.  In every case that the fire department is called, the Kraft Heinz Tulare and Tulare City Fire Department HAZMAT Response Teams will be placed on standby and an ambulance will be called to the scene.

7.0	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the Process Hazard Analysis (what-if PHA) completed for ammonia, a list of action items were developed and are being monitored to determine if implementation was accomplished.  Some of the projects undertaken to improve safety at the facility include an operational test program for ammonia sensors, operator training (all operators attended the University of Wisconsin ammonia training course), and all ammonia valves are being tracked on a spreadsheet for maintenance schedules.  There are numerous examples of proposed safety improvements as a result of the PHA.  These include:

1.	Addition of an auto suction system. (Implementation, 2003)

2.	Preventive Maintenance for Hansen low low. (Implementation, 2003)

3.	Preventive Maint

enance for Penn differential switch. (Implementation, 2003)

4.	Safeguards for failure of float switch force feed down stream of LPRA's. (Implementation, 2003)
